text: {| |} RFA Fort Langley (A230) was a stores ship of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary. The ship was launched in October 1944 as SS Montebello Park as merchant steamship constructed for Canada’s Merchant Navy in 1944 during the Second World War as part of Canada's Park ship program. She was built by Victoria MD in Victoria, British Columbia, Canada.Not to be taken as the Montebello Park completed on 31/01/45 by West Coast Shipbuilders and scrapped in Spain in 1966 On 18 May 1945 she was commissioned as Fort Langley. Transferred to the RFA in May 1954, she was decommissioned in February 1970, and laid up at Devonport. Fort Langley arrived at Bilbao for scrapping on 21 July 1970. Fort and Park ship were the Canadian equivalent of the American Liberty ships. All three shared a similar design by J.L. Thompson and Sons of Sunderland, England. Fort ships had a triple expansion steam engine and a single screw propellor. During World War II, 28 were lost to enemy action, and four were lost due to accidents. Many of the surviving 166 ships passed to the United States Maritime Commission. The last recorded scrapping was in 1985, and two ships, the former and , were listed on Lloyd's Register until 1992. ==See also== *RFA Fort Charlotte (A236) *RFA Fort Duquesne (A229) *RFA Fort Rosalie (A186) *Fort Cataraqui (ship) *SS Montebello for 1920 tanker ==References== Category:Ships of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary Category:1944 ships
title: RFA Fort Langley (A230)
